conclusion: To determine if Object A and B have the same acceleration at \( t_1 \), analyze the slopes of their velocity-time graphs.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, represented as \( a = \frac{dv}{dt} \). In a velocity-time graph, the slope of the tangent line represents acceleration.
At \( t_1 \), Object A's velocity changes linearly with time, showing a straight line segment between \( t=0 \) and \( t=t_2 \).
The slope of Object A's straight line segment can be calculated using \( \text{slope} = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \), indicating constant acceleration.
At \( t_1 \), Object B's velocity changes nonlinearly, showing a curved segment.
To find Object B's acceleration at \( t_1 \), find the slope of the tangent line to the curve at \( t_1 \).
The tangent line slope for Object B at \( t_1 \) appears different from Object A's straight line slope.
The slope of Object A's line is constant and visually estimated, while Object B's tangent line slope at \( t_1 \) is less steep.
Since the slopes are different, Object A and B do not have the same acceleration at \( t_1 \).
Final answer: No, the two objects do not have the same acceleration at time \( t_1 \).
